Effect of MgO addition to Cu-Ni/Al2O3 catalysts on glycerol hydrogenolysis in continuous reactor without external hydrogen Mendonca Victor G.S. Souza Supervision Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition ⁎ Escola de Química – Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ), Centro de Tecnologia, Bloco E, sala 206, CEP 21941-909 Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil Escola de Química – Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ), Centro de Tecnologia Bloco E, sala 206 Rio de Janeiro RJ CEP 21941-909 Brazil Escola de Química – Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ), Centro de Tecnologia, Bloco E, sala 206, CEP 21941–909, Rio de Janeiro/RJ, Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. Cu-Ni/xMgO-Al2O3 catalysts with x = 0, 10, 20 and 30 wt% were prepared and evaluated in glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) at 250 oC, pressure of 40 bar for 30 h, without addition of external hydrogen. The addition of MgO to alumina decreased the surface area, increased the Cu/Ni dispersion and the number of basic sites. The highest 1,2-PDO yield was achieved by Cu-Ni/30%MgO-Al2O3 catalyst: 50% after 6 h of reaction; it decreases to 25% after 30 h. The decrease in 1,2-PDO yield is accompanied by an increase in acetol yield, showing that the rate limiting step for MgO-Al2O3 catalysts is the hydrogenation of acetol to 1,2-PDO because there is not enough hydrogen in reaction medium. For Cu-Ni/MgO catalyst, the reaction pathway changed to the basic route, with preferential formation of lactic acid (50% of lactic acid yield in the first hours of reaction). Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Glycerol Hydrogenolysis 1,2-Propanediol MgO Alumina Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biodiesel production has been increasing worldwide with regulatory and socioeconomic motivations for renewable energy. The main byproduct of the transesterification reaction used for biodiesel production is glycerol: 100 kg of crude glycerol for each ton of biodiesel [1]. Currently, biodiesel is the primary glycerol source and the rapid increase in biodiesel production has led to a surplus of glycerol in the world market. The prices of crude glycerol have fallen down to virtually zero and even to a negative mark as producers of biodiesel are forced to pay to have it taken away from their plants [2]. Glycerol is an interesting platform molecule from which a wide variety of high value-added chemicals can be produced for different sectors. Among the chemicals, the most remarkable are glycols: mainly ethylene glycol, 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO), and 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PDO), which can be produced through glycerol hydrogenolysis [3,4]. The hydrogenolysis of the primary hydroxy group yields 1,2-PDO (or propylene glycol), a commodity chemical used as industrial solvent and functional fluid (antifreeze/deicing, lubrication), additive in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, foods and paints, and also for production of polyester resins [3–5]. The glycerol hydrogenolysis involves a C-O bond dissociation and the subsequent addition of hydrogen. Due to the low solubility of hydrogen in aqueous solutions, hydrogenolysis reactors usually operate at high hydrogen pressures [3]. This drawback may be overcome using in situ hydrogen generation by glycerol reforming. Moreover, as hydrogen is generally derived from fossil fuels, the use of hydrogen produced in situ from glycerol makes hydrogenolysis a more environmentally attractive process. Noble metals, like Ru, Rh, Pt, and Pd, are commonly used as heterogeneous catalysts for the glycerol hydrogenolysis, because they are able to activate hydrogen molecules and present high activity for glycerol conversion. However, non-noble metals, such as Cu, Co, and Ni, can also present good catalytic activity for C-O bond cleavage, besides having much lower prices. Among non-noble metals, copper is most often selected as active component in the catalysts because of its intrinsic ability to cleave C-O bonds without affecting C-C bonds, which increases the selectivity to 1,2-PDO [1,4,5]. On the other hand, nickel is the most used metal in catalysts for reforming reactions of oxygenated compounds due to its high activity to break C-C and C-H bonds [3,6,7]. The majority of the glycerol hydrogenolysis studies have been conducted at high hydrogen pressures. Among the works without addition of external hydrogen, most of them use batch reactors [8–14]. There are few studies that reported continuous operation, without H2 addition. Mane and Rode [15] used a Cu-Al catalyst prepared by co-precipitation in a fixed-bed reactor for glycerol hydrogenolysis under 20 bar of N2 pressure and obtained 90% of glycerol conversion with 25% of 1,2-PDO selectivity, at 220 oC. Our group reported 80% of glycerol conversion with 25% of 1,2-PDO yield for Cu-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst in continuous glycerol hydrogenolysis at 250 oC and 40 bar, without external hydrogen [16]. Cai et al. [17] also evaluated Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts in continuous glycerol hydrogenolysis without H2 addition; they compared Cu-Ni/Al2O3 and Cu-Ni/TiO2 and obtained similar results with both catalysts: 25–30% of glycerol conversion and 28–32% of 1,2-PDO selectivity at 230 oC and 35 bar. More recently, Raso et al. [18] reported 42% of glycerol conversion and 71% of 1,2-PDO selectivity for Ni/Al-Fe catalyst at 227 oC and 34 bar. It is well reported in the literature that the mechanism of glycerol hydrogenolysis is strongly influenced by the acid/base character of the reaction medium [1,5]. In acidic conditions, the hydrogenolysis performs in consecutive glycerol dehydration to acetol (on acid sites) and acetol hydrogenation to 1,2-PDO (on metal sites). In basic solutions, glycerol could dehydrogenate to glyceraldehyde in first, followed by dehydration to 2-hydroxypropenal (on basic sites) and then hydrogenation to 1,2-PDO [5,19–21]. γ-Al2O3 is widely used as catalyst support due to its high surface area and mechanical resistance; its acidic nature favors the formation of acetol as intermediate in glycerol hydrogenolysis [3,16]. However, γ-Al2O3 can suffer from hydrothermal instability under aqueous phase at high pressure, with transformation into boehmite [16], and its acidity favors deactivation due to coke formation [1,3,5]. Basic metal oxides, such as MgO, can be used as promoters for the γ-Al2O3, improving the thermal stability, enhancing the reversibility of the redox reactions suffered by the metal phase and also decreasing coke formation [3,22]. Yuan et al. [23] observed that Pt/MgO exhibited higher activity than Pt/Al2O3 for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol in a batch reactor under 30 atm of H2. Balaraju et al. [24] reported a direct relation between glycerol conversion and catalyst basicity for Cu/MgO catalysts in glycerol hydrogenolysis under 40 bar of H2. Zhou et al. [14] compared Cu/MgO and Cu/Al2O3 for glycerol hydrogenolysis in a batch reactor without H2 addition and showed that the basic support was more favorable to 1,2-PDO formation than the acidic one. One of the main challenges when using glycerol reforming as hydrogen source for hydrogenolysis is to achieve high yields to 1,2-PDO because of the competition between C-O and C-C bond cleavage reactions. Delgado et al. [25] observed that although the presence of acidic sites is desirable for the dehydration reactions (i.e. for C-O cleavages), a too high quantity of these sites can promote excessive C-C bond cleavages via an acidic cracking mechanism. The addition of MgO to γ-Al2O3 is an alternative to control the acid/base character of the support and thus increase the yield to 1,2-PDO. In this work, Cu-Ni/MgO-Al2O3 catalysts with different MgO contents (10, 20 and 30 wt%) were evaluated for glycerol hydrogenolysis in continuous reactor, using hydrogen generated in situ by glycerol reforming. Our aim is to investigate the effect of MgO loading on the catalyst basicity and its influence in the catalytic performance for glycerol hydrogenolysis, in terms of glycerol conversion, yield to 1,2-PDO and possible reaction pathways. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation MgO-Al2O3 supports were prepared by the wet impregnation, with MgO content of 10, 20 and 30 wt%. γ-Al2O3 (BASF) was used without further treatment. Appropriate amount of magnesium nitrate (Mg(NO3)2.6H2O) (Sigma-Aldrich) was dissolved in deionized water and added to γ-Al2O3 in a rotary evaporator. After 2 h of rotation at room temperature for homogenization, the water was removed by evaporation at 80 oC under vacuum. Finally, the obtained material was dried at 110 °C for 12 h, and calcined at 500 °C for 3 h under flowing air (60 mL min-1). MgO was obtained from calcination of magnesium nitrate under these same conditions. Cu-Ni catalysts supported on MgO-Al2O3, γ-Al2O3 and MgO were prepared by the same wet impregnation method, using Cu(NO3)2.6H2O and Ni(NO3)2.6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich) as precursors. The CuO and NiO loading of all catalysts was 20 wt% of each oxide. The prepared catalysts will be referred to as CuNiAl for Cu-Ni/Al2O3, CuNiMg for Cu-Ni/MgO, and CuNixMgAl (where x is 10, 20 or 30) for CuNi/MgO-Al2O3 catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The chemical composition of the catalysts was determined by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) using a Rigaku Primini spectrometer, equipped with X-ray generator tube of palladium. The textural characteristics were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption at − 196 oC in a Micromeritics TriStar 3000. The samples were outgassed for 24 h at 300 °C in vacuum. The specific surface area was obtained using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and pore volume by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded in a Rigaku Miniflex II diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator with CuKα radiation (30 kV and 15 mA). The measurements were carried out with steps of 0.05° using a counting time of 1 s per step and over the 2θ range of 5–90°. Reduced catalysts were analyzed after ex situ reduction under the same conditions used before the catalytic tests and spent catalysts were analyzed without any other treatment after reaction. The average size of the Cu-Ni alloy crystallites was calculated by the Scherrer equation (Eq. (1)), using the diffraction peak correspondent to (200) plane: (1) d = k λ β . cos θ where d is the average diameter of the crystals (Å), k is a constant that depends on the particle shape (for sphere, k = 0.9), λ is the wavelength of the X-ray source (for CuKα, λ = 1.5488 Å), β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) in radians and θ is the diffraction angle. The corresponding metallic dispersion (D) was estimated according to Anderson [26] (Eq. (2)): (2) D= 6 V m d. A m where Vm is the atomic volume (0.0118 nm3 for Cu and 0.0109 nm3 for Ni), d is the crystallite size (in nm) and Am is the surface area of a single atom (0.068 nm2 for Cu and 0.0649 nm2 for Ni). For Cu-Ni alloy, Vm and Am were calculated from an average value of Cu and Ni, considering the atomic fraction of each element as determined by XRF (see Supplementary Material). The reduction profiles of the catalysts were obtained by temperature- programmed reduction (TPR). The analysis was performed in a conventional apparatus equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The samples were pre-treated for 30 min at 150 °C under argon flow (30 mL min-1). After cooling, they were heated from room temperature to 1000 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 and a flow rate of 30 mL min-1 of 2% H2/Ar. The catalyst basicity was investigated by temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD), which was performed using a mass spectrometer QMG-200 Prisma Plus (Pfeiffer). The samples were firstly reduced in situ using a mixture of 1.8% H2/Ar (30 mL min-1) and heating up to 800 °C (10 °C min-1) for 30 min. Then, the samples were cooled down to room temperature using He. CO2 adsorption was carried out at room temperature with 10% CO2/He (30 mL min-1) for 30 min, followed by purging with He for 1 h. The desorption of the chemisorbed CO2 was carried out by heating the samples up to 800 °C at a rate of 20 °C min-1, with flowing He (30 mL min-1). The ratio m/z = 44 was used for quantification of CO2. 2.3 Hydrogenolysis of glycerol The glycerol hydrogenolysis was carried out in a fixed bed reactor of Inconel 625, with internal diameter of 0.5 cm and length of 15 cm. The catalysts in the form of pellets were reduced in situ at 800 oC with a mixture of 30% H2/N2 for 1 h. The aqueous solution of glycerol (10 vol%) was injected to the reactor by an HPLC pump (Eldex 1SM), and the flow rate (0.041 mL min-1) was adjusted to obtain a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 2 h-1, using 1.25 g of catalyst. The reactions were performed for a period of 30 h, at 250 oC and 40 bar of pressure. The minimum pressure to maintain the reaction medium in liquid phase at 250 oC is 38.7 bar (calculated in Hysys using Gibbs Reactor and UNIQUAC model). A pressure of 40 bar was chosen to ensure that the system was in a liquid phase. The liquid samples were collected every hour and analyzed in a Shimadzu Prominence HPLC with Bio-Rad Aminex HPX-87 H column (300 ×7.8 mm) at 30 °C, using 0.01 M H2SO4 as eluent at 0.6 mL min-1, and ultraviolet (UV) and refractive index detectors. The samples were prepared by diluting aliquots of the reaction mixture in an aqueous solution of 0.01 M H2SO4. The catalytic performance in terms of glycerol conversion, conversion to liquid, selectivity and yield to 1,2-PDO, acetol, and lactic acid was calculated according to Eqs. (3)–(6). • Glycerol conversion: (3) X ( % ) = M Glycerol in − M Glycerol out M Glycerol in × 100 where M Glycerol in is the molar concentration of glycerol in the feed, M Glycerol out is the molar concentration of glycerol after the reaction; • Glycerol conversion to liquids: (4) X L % = ∑ M i M Glycerol in × 100 where M i is molar concentration of product i (1,2-PDO, acetol and lactic acid); • Selectivity to product i: (5) S i % = M i ∑ M i × 100 • Yield to product i: (6) Y i ( % ) = X L ( % ) × S i ( % ) 100 The molar concentration of glycerol was used directly to calculate the conversion, as in Eqs. (3) and (4), because the glycerol concentration in the feed is only 10 vol% (in water) and the conversion to gas is relatively small, thus the total liquid flow rate is approximately constant. Turnover frequencies (TOF) values were calculated according to Eq. (7), based on 1,2-PDO formation from 23 to 30 h of reaction, using the glycerol conversion to liquid and selectivity to 1,2-PDO, and the metallic dispersions displayed in Table 2. (7) TOF h - 1 = Glycerol feed molar flow ( molh − 1 ) x X L % x S 1 , 2 - PDO ( % ) surface active sites ( mol ) The external and internal mass transfer limitation were evaluated using the Mears and Weisz-Prater criterion, respectively. The calculation is presented in the Supplementary Material. The value of Mears criterion was found to be equal to 0.033 (< 0.15) and Weisz-Prater criterion was 0.15 (< 1), which assures no diffusional limitations for the glycerol hydrogenolysis under the reaction conditions used in this work. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The chemical compositions of the supports and catalysts measured by XRF are shown in Table 1. The measured values are similar to nominal values and small differences can be explained by the uncertainty of the analysis. Thus, the synthesis method was effective in the preparation of catalysts with the desired chemical composition. The textural properties of the catalysts measured by N2 physisorption are also displayed in Table 1. All the catalysts presented pore sizes in the range of 20–500 Å, indicating the predominance of mesoporous in the materials. The adsorption-desorption isotherms of nitrogen for all catalysts exhibited the type IV pattern, which is typical of mesoporous materials. There was a decrease in the BET surface area and pore volume by the addition of MgO to alumina, which can be associated with the blockage of alumina pores by MgO precursor during wet impregnation. Menezes et al. [22] observed a decrease in BET area from 201 for γ-Al2O3 to 149 m2 g-1 for 10 wt% MgO-Al2O3 (prepared by wet impregnation and calcined at 500 oC). The metal addition also causes this same effect on the alumina-containing support. The reduction in BET area by nickel/copper and magnesium oxide addition on alumina was also reported in other studies [27,28]. The catalyst supported on MgO presented the lowest BET area and pore volume, which is expected when this support is prepared from calcination of magnesium nitrate precursor [29,30]. In the case of MgO support, there was an increase in the BET area and pore volume with metal impregnation, which was also observed by other authors [30,31]. This increase in the values of the textural properties of the CuNiMg catalyst may be associated with the characteristics of CuO phase, because pure CuO calcined at 500 °C presents a BET surface area of 37.1 m2 g-1 and pore volume 0.287 cm3 g-1 [32]. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the supports and the calcined, reduced, and spent catalysts. MgO support exhibited sharp diffraction lines at 36.9o, 42.9o, 62.3o, 74.8o and 78.7o, corresponding to periclase MgO phase (JCPDS 45–0946). All supports containing alumina showed peaks related to γ-Al2O3 at 2θ equal to 37.6o, 45.8o and 66.8o (JCPDS 01–1303) and the peaks related to MgO phase increase in intensity as the MgO loading increases. A shift in γ-Al2O3 diffraction peaks with addition of MgO was not observed, showing that there was no introduction of Mg species into alumina lattice. The interaction between MgO and Al2O3 is relatively weak, with formation of MgO crystals on the alumina surface (and without formation of MgAl2O4 spinel phase). This can be attributed both to the impregnation methodology and low calcination temperature used in the support synthesis [27,33,34]. All calcined catalyst presented characteristic peaks of CuO at 35.5°, 38.7° and 48.7° (JCPDS 48–1548), NiO at 37.3o, 43.3° and 62.9° (JCPDS 47–1049) and also the characteristic support structure. The formation of small amount of NiAl2O4 spinel phase cannot be discarded because its peaks are located at 2θ equal to 37.0o, 45.0o and 65.6o (JCPDS 10–0339), close to NiO and alumina peaks. However, the formation of spinel phase is not favored under low calcination temperature, as described previously [35,36]. After reduction, XRD patterns showed that both CuO and NiO were completely reduced, with formation of Cu-Ni peaks at intermediate positions between Cu0 (peaks at 43.3°, 50.5° and 74.2°, JCPDS 04–0836) and Ni0 (peaks at 44.5°, 51.9° and 76.4°, JCPDS 04–0850) (see Fig. S1 of Supplementary Material). Thus, the copper is forming an alloy with nickel [36–38]. The presence of two peaks at intermediate position (see Fig. S2) shows that there is an alloy more enriched in Ni, and another one enriched in Cu. The alloys with more than 50 at% Cu are expected to consist of two phases: a Cu-rich alloy (about 95 at% Cu) and a Ni-rich alloy (about 35 at% Cu) [39]. Experimental lattice parameters of the metallic phase, obtained from XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts and displayed in Table S1, presented intermediate values between nickel and copper, which have FCC structure with lattice parameter a = 3.5238 Å and 3.6150 Å, respectively [16]. The actual composition of the NixCu1−x alloy can be calculated applying the Vegard's law (a NixCu1-x = x. a Ni +(1-x).a Cu ) [38,40,41]; the values are shown in Table S1. The Ni total composition of the alloys is very close to the nominal composition for all alumina-containing catalysts (considering the areas obtained from deconvolution of the (111) peak). In the case of CuNiMg catalyst, the sum of Ni content of the two different alloys is lower than total Ni loading, because part of the nickel is probably forming a NiO-MgO solid solution [29,42]. After reaction, most of the nickel and copper were maintained in their reduced state; however, part of the copper was oxidized to Cu2O, with peaks at 36.5o, 42.4o and 61.5o (JCPDS 78–2076). Due to the formation of Cu2O, the peaks of the Cu-Ni alloy were shifted to larger angles, showing that the alloy was enriched in Ni. Yun et al. [11] observed formation of Cu2O on Cu-Ni catalysts supported on mesoporous alumina after 10 h of glycerol hydrogenolysis at 220 oC in a batch reactor, under N2 pressure. Pudi et al. [43] reported the formation of CuO and Cu2O on Cu/MgO catalyst after reuse in glycerol hydrogenolysis at 210 oC in a batch reactor, even under high H2 pressure. For CuNiAl and CuNi10MgAl catalysts, γ-Al2O3 was partially transformed into boehmite (AlOOH), with main reflections at 12.8o, 14.5o, 25.3o, 28.3o, 34.5o, 38.3o, 44.6o, 45.8o, 49.5o, 51.9o, 55.3o, 64.2o, 65.2o, and 72.1o (JCPDS 03–0065). The formation of boehmite was also observed for Ni/Al2O3 [44] and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts [45] after aqueous-phase reforming of glycerol at 220–230 oC. On the other hand, MgO was completely transformed into Mg(OH)2 (JCPDS 07–0239) and MgCO3 (JCPDS 08–0479) after the reaction, for CuNiMg catalyst. This transformation was also reported by Zhou et al. [14] for Cu/MgO catalyst after 23 h of glycerol hydrogenolysis at 200 oC in a batch reactor, without addition of external of H2. Guo et al. [46] observed that MgO on Co/MgO catalyst was hydrated to Mg(OH)2 after 9 h of glycerol hydrogenolysis at 200 oC in a batch reactor, under H2 pressure. The catalysts supported on MgO-Al2O3 also presented some formation of Mg(OH)2 after reaction. The crystallite sizes of Cu-Ni alloy in the reduced catalysts are presented in Table 2, as well as the metallic dispersion after reduction. There was a decrease in Cu-Ni crystallite size through the addition of MgO, compared to the CuNiAl catalyst. Lisboa et al. [47] observed that the presence of MgO reduced the Ni ensemble particle size on Ni/Al2O3 catalysts, probably by decoration of Ni particles by magnesium species. Other authors [22,42] also studied the effect of magnesium oxide incorporation on Ni/Al2O3 catalyst and observed an increase in nickel dispersion by MgO addition. Although the BET area of MgO is much smaller than that of Al2O3, the Cu/Ni dispersion of CuNiMg catalyst was higher than that of CuNiAl catalyst. The formation of NiO-MgO solid-solution may inhibit the sintering of nickel in a certain extent, thus promoting the nickel dispersion [48]. Fig. 2 shows the reduction profiles of the catalysts. The catalyst supported on alumina presented two reduction peaks, at 270 °C and 400 °C. The first peak is mainly related to the reduction of CuO, while the second one corresponds to the reduction of NiO [16,17,35]. Considering that pure bulk CuO and NiO have reduction temperatures close to 230 and 420 oC, respectively [35], metal phases are in weak interaction with the support. Some authors reported higher temperatures for nickel reduction in Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts: around 530 oC for Cu-Ni/Al2O3 catalysts [49] and 710 oC for Cu-Ni-Mg-Al catalysts [37]. Reduction temperatures above 700 oC are usually associated with NiAl2O4 reduction [27,35–37]; therefore, the presence of this spinel phase can be ruled out in our case. Similar Ni/Al2O3 monometallic catalysts presented much higher reduction temperatures (up to 850 oC); thus, the presence of Cu is beneficial to the reduction of NiO species and there is a spillover effect on Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts [11,16,17,38]. For catalysts supported on MgO-Al2O3, both reduction peaks are fully overlapped, with maximum at 290–295 oC, showing a decrease in reduction temperature of NiO with addition of MgO. The complete overlapping of Ni and Cu reduction peaks in bimetallic catalysts was also reported by other authors [11,17]. The CuNiMg catalyst presented the maximum reduction peak at 330 oC, a temperature higher than those of MgO-Al2O3 catalysts, which suggests that Cu and Ni crystals may be with stronger interaction with MgO. A Cu/MgO catalyst prepared by the same methodology showed the reduction temperature at 415 oC [30], which confirms the synergy between Cu and Ni in decreasing their reduction temperature. The catalysts supported on MgO-containing supports also presented a small reduction band at about 565–745 oC, which can be related to a partial reduction of NiO contained in NiO-MgO solid-solution. This band is more intense for CuNiMg catalyst. In general, the lattice Ni2+ in NiO-MgO solid solution cannot be reduced when the temperature is lower than 800 oC [48,50]; thus the presence of copper favors NiO reduction in MgO lattice. Table 2 presents the total reduction degree of both CuO and NiO of the supported catalysts. The alumina-containing catalysts presented reduction degrees in the range of 80–92%, showing an incomplete reduction of the metallic phases, despite the weak interaction with the support. The lowest reduction degree (75%) was presented by the CuNiMg catalyst, which can be related to the difficulty in reducing the NiO contained in the NiO-MgO solid solution. CO2 desorption profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 3. For Cu-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, the peaks are centered at low temperatures (80–130 oC). The addition of MgO caused a great increase in CO2 desorption because of its basic sites and the TPD peak intensity increases with MgO loading. For MgO-Al2O3 catalysts, CO2 desorption occurs mainly at 250–520 oC; there are also small peaks at 120–180 oC. These desorption peaks at low temperature (< 200 oC) may be ascribed to the weakly chemisorbed CO2 on the surface hydroxyl groups, resulting in formation of bicarbonates [34]. According to Aramendía et al. [51], the basic sites can be classified based on their different strengths (different CO2 desorption temperature, TD): low (TD below 400 oC), medium (TD between 400 and 600 oC) and high strength basic sites (TD over 600 oC). Thus, the catalysts presented only low and medium strength basic sites. Table 2 shows the total number of basic sites per gram of catalyst, the density of basic sites and the proportion of low, medium and high strength basic sites for each catalyst. There is a great increase in the number of basic sites with MgO addition, as well as in the density of basic sites and proportion of medium strength basic sites. Apuzzo et al. [52] reported an increase in basicity from 160 to 340 and 400 μmolCO2 g-1 by 12 and 20 wt% MgO addition on alumina. Menezes et al. [22] observed an increase in basicity from 76 for Ni/Al2O3 to 182 μmolCO2 g-1 for Ni/10%MgO-Al2O3. The amount of basic sites reported here are in accordance with these results. The CuNiMg catalyst presented the highest amount of basic sites (1520.5 μmolCO2 g-1), much higher than those of MgO-Al2O3 catalysts. Wurzler et al. [29] reported a number of basic sites of 4575 μmolCO2 g-1 for 5%Ni/MgO catalyst, where the support was also prepared by calcination of magnesium nitrate at 500 oC (with BET area of 3 m2g-1). On the other hand, the number of basic sites reported by Bruno et al. [30] for 20% Cu/MgO was only 203 μmolCO2 g-1 (MgO was prepared by the same methodology reported here, with BET area of 16 m2g-1). Thus, the amount of basic sites calculated from CO2-TPD can vary significantly for similar catalysts. 3.2 Catalytic tests Fig. 4 shows the glycerol conversion and conversion to liquids obtained in activity tests performed at 250 °C and 40 bar. Firstly, it is worth noting that pure Al2O3 and MgO did not give detectable glycerol conversion, suggesting that the metal sites are prerequisite for the reaction, as also shown in the literature [53,54]. The CuNiAl catalyst presented the highest glycerol conversion after 6 h of reaction (85%), and it remained relatively stable thereafter (between 81% and 90%). The catalysts containing 10% and 20% of MgO showed a small decrease in glycerol conversion from the first to the second day (from about 72–78% to 53–65%). For CuNi30MgAl and CuNiMg catalysts, the glycerol conversion remained almost constant after 4 h of reaction, 65–75% and 58–64%, respectively. Regarding the conversion to liquid, CuNiAl catalyst presented the lowest value after 3 h of reaction (42%), which remained almost the same until the end of reaction. There was a small decrease in the conversion to liquid from the fourth hour of reaction for CuNi10MgAl and CuNi20MgAl catalysts, with values close to CuNiAl in the last hours. The CuNi30MgAl catalyst reached 70% of conversion to liquid after 6 h and it stabilized at about 55% at the end of reaction. For CuNiMg catalyst, the conversion to liquid decreased from 70% at 6 h to 20% at 30 h of reaction, showing its severe deactivation over time. The complete transformation of MgO into Mg(OH)2 and MgCO3, as shown in XRD pattern of CuNiMg after reaction, may explain its deactivation. The difference between glycerol conversion and conversion to liquid is due to glycerol reforming to H2 and CO2 (a small amount of CH4 can also be formed by methanation reaction [16]). This difference is greater for CuNiAl catalyst (considering alumina-containing catalysts), showing its higher activity for reforming reaction and, consequently, larger availability of H2 in the reaction medium. Iriondo et al. [55] reported that lower Ni dispersion of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts provided a higher activity for aqueous-phase reforming of glycerol. The lower Cu-Ni dispersion of CuNiAl catalyst (Table 2) can also be related to its higher glycerol conversion by reforming. The hydrogen formed by aqueous-phase reforming of glycerol is fundamental for one of the steps of hydrogenolysis, which is the hydrogenation of acetol (in acid conditions) or 2-hydroxypropenal (in basic conditions) to 1,2-PDO (as discussed previously in the Introduction). The hydrogen adatom present in active sites, formed by in situ reforming, is directly available for the hydrogenolysis reaction, avoiding the need for high hydrogen pressures [3]. The connection between these two reactions (aqueous-phase reforming and hydrogenolysis) lies in the fact that they can be operated at the same conditions (220–250 °C, 20–50 bar). In general, the competition between glycerol reforming and hydrogenolysis decreases the yield to 1,2-PDO as compared to the reaction performed under external H2 pressure [3,16,17]. Thus, one of the main challenges when using glycerol reforming as hydrogen source for hydrogenolysis is to obtain a proper balance between C-C bond cleavage reactions that lead to the production of hydrogen and the C-O bond cleavage that lead to 1,2-PDO formation. The combination of Ni and Cu active phases and the adjustment of the acid/base properties of the support are efficient ways to achieve this balance. Fig. 5 shows the yields to 1,2-PDO, acetol and lactic acid, the main products of glycerol hydrogenolysis under the reaction conditions used here. No other liquid product was detected, such as 1,3-PDO, ethylene glycol, acrolein, 1-propanol, 2-propanol and ethanol. The highest 1,2-PDO yield was achieved by CuNi30MgAl catalyst after 6 h of reaction (50%), and it decreased to 25% in the last hours of reaction. The catalysts with MgO content of 0–20% also presented a decrease in 1,2-PDO yield along the reaction, with values around 20% at 30 h. The decrease in 1,2-PDO yield is accompanied by an increase in acetol yield from 7–13% to 20–28%. The oxidation of Cu to Cu2O observed in XRD of the used catalysts may be related to the decrease in 1,2-PDO yield, because Cu phase is essential for acetol hydrogenation to 1,2-PDO [11,20,56]. The increase in acetol yield is less pronounced for CuNiAl catalyst. This shows that the rate limiting step for MgO-Al2O3 catalysts is the hydrogenation of acetol to 1,2-PDO because there is not enough H2 in reaction medium. Cai et al. [57] reported a linear correlation between 1,2-PDO yield and Cu dispersion on Cu-ZrO2-Al2O3 catalysts, under H2 atmosphere. On the other hand, Cai et al. [17] showed that Ni/Cu/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/Cu/TiO2 presented almost the same glycerol conversion and 1,2-PDO selectivity under nitrogen atmosphere, despite the much higher Cu dispersion of the latter. The higher Cu-Ni dispersion of MgO-Al2O3 catalysts favors the conversion of acetol to 1,2-PDO in the first hours of reaction; 1,2-PDO yields were higher than those of CuNiAl in the first hours. However, as the reaction proceeds, 1,2-PDO yield decreases more sharply for MgO-containing catalysts because of the low availability of H2 for acetol hydrogenation to 1,2-PDO. The 1,2-PDO yield is approximately constant at 15–20% for CuNiMg catalyst from 2 h of reaction and there is no acetol formation, showing that the reaction pathway follows the basic route. Under basic conditions, 1,2-PDO is produced from glycerol in a similar way to lactic acid: glycerol is first dehydrogenated to glyceraldehyde, followed by dehydration to 2-hydroxypropenal (on basic sites). If 2-hydroxypropenal is directly hydrogenated, it forms 1,2-PDO; if 2-hydroxypropenal undergoes a molecular rearrangement, known as keto-enol tautomerization, it turns into pyruvaldehyde, and finally the pyruvaldehyde is converted to lactic acid by intramolecular Cannizzaro reaction [30,58–61]. This last step is also favored in the presence of basic sites. In general, lactic acid formation is only observed in the presence of homogeneous bases (NaOH or KOH) [30,58,59], but it can also be catalyzed by basic heterogeneous oxides [37,60,61]. The formation of the reaction intermediates such as glyceraldehyde, 2-hydroxypropenal, and pyruvaldehyde was observed in some studies [62–64]. Most studies on the conversion of glycerol to lactic acid do not note the formation of such intermediates. This may indicate that these intermediates may be quickly converted into subsequent products [65]. It is worth noting that none of these intermediates were detected in the liquid product of this study. All catalysts containing MgO presented formation of lactic acid because of its basicity; the hydroxyl ions can be generated from the MgO hydration to Mg(OH)2, which has been proved by the XRD characterization of the used catalysts. For CuNiMg catalyst, the lactic acid yield achieved 50% in the first hours of reaction due to its higher basicity (Table 2), and then decreased to 5–10%, with similar values to the MgO-Al2O3 catalysts. Thus, the complete transformation of MgO into Mg(OH)2 and MgCO3 for this catalyst may be responsible for its deactivation. The CuNiAl catalyst showed no formation of lactic acid. The following order of TOF (calculated according to Eq. (7)) was obtained: CuNiAl (1.95 h-1) > CuNiMg (1.14 h-1) > CuNi30MgAl (0.86 h-1) > CuNi20MgAl (0.75 h-1) > CuNi10MgAl (0.50 h-1). Although CuNi30MgAl catalyst presents the highest reaction rate, its greater dispersion than CuNiAl and CuNiMg catalysts decreased its TOF. Among the catalysts with similar dispersion, CuNi30MgAl catalyst showed the highest TOF. However, it should be noted that all TOF values are in the same order of magnitude, thus the catalysts presented similar specific activities. It is very difficult to compare these values of TOFs with others in the literature, because most of the studies were carried out in batch reactor and H2 pressure. Xia et al. [19] reported a TOF of 7.5 h-1 for Cu0.4/Mg5.6Al2O8.6 catalyst, at 180 oC and 2.0 MPa of H2. Azri et al. [66] calculated a TOF of 0.78 h-1 for Cu/Al2O3 catalyst, at 200 oC and 4.0 MPa of H2. These works used batch reactors. The studies of glycerol hydrogenolysis that used fixed bed reactors without H2 addition [15,17,18] did not report TOF values. A comparison between the results of CuNi30MgAl catalyst, which showed the highest values of glycerol conversion to liquid and 1,2-PDO yield, and other works in the literature that also studied glycerol hydrogenolysis in the absence of external hydrogen is shown in Table 3. A direct comparison with studies performed in batch reactor is not possible, but it can be clearly seen that the results of CuNi30MgAl catalyst are very promising when compared with other works that also used a fixed bed reactor. 4 Conclusions Cu-Ni catalysts supported on MgO-Al2O3 were prepared by wet impregnation, containing 20 wt% of CuO and NiO. XRD profiles showed formation of Cu-Ni alloy on bimetallic catalysts after reduction. The addition of MgO to alumina caused a decrease in the Cu/Ni crystallite size, increasing the metallic dispersion, a decrease in the reduction temperature of Ni species, and a great increase in the amount of basic sites. The catalysts were evaluated on glycerol hydrogenolysis in continuous reactor, at 250 oC and 40 bar of pressure, without hydrogen addition. The catalyst supported on Al2O3 presented higher values of glycerol conversion but lower conversion to liquid, showing that glycerol reforming is preferred over hydrogenolysis. The 1,2-PDO yield is higher for MgO-Al2O3 catalysts, which was associated with their higher Cu/Ni dispersion. The highest 1,2-PDO yield was obtained for catalyst containing 30% of MgO: 50% after 6 h and 25% after 30 h of reaction. For alumina-containing catalysts the reaction mainly follows the acid route, with formation of acetol as intermediate, due to glycerol dehydration. The decrease in 1,2-PDO yield during the reaction is mainly related to the low availability of H2 for hydrogenation of acetol to 1,2-PDO. The catalyst supported on MgO did not show any acetol formation and the reaction pathway changed to the basic route, with preferential formation of lactic acid (50% of lactic acid yield in the first hours of reaction). coredata.dc:description: Cu-Ni/xMgO-Al2O3 catalysts with x = 0, 10, 20 and 30 wt% were prepared and evaluated in glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) at 250 oC, pressure of 40 bar for 30 h, without addition of external hydrogen. The addition of MgO to alumina decreased the surface area, increased the Cu/Ni dispersion and the number of basic sites. The highest 1,2-PDO yield was achieved by Cu-Ni/30%MgO-Al2O3 catalyst: 50% after 6 h of reaction; it decreases to 25% after 30 h. The decrease in 1,2-PDO yield is accompanied by an increase in acetol yield, showing that the rate limiting step for MgO-Al2O3 catalysts is the hydrogenation of acetol to 1,2-PDO because there is not enough hydrogen in reaction medium. For Cu-Ni/MgO catalyst, the reaction pathway changed to the basic route, with preferential formation of lactic acid (50% of lactic acid yield in the first hours of reaction).
coredata.dc:title: Effect of MgO addition to Cu-Ni/Al2O3 catalysts on glycerol hydrogenolysis in continuous reactor without external hydrogen
